text:
I guess the “compactness” of it works well for mobile users but for desktop I much rather like something such as a sticky table of content on the side.

Maybe an improvement I could think of for this version would be to have a way to jump back to the table of content from each of the headings. In the example from Dominic I found myself having to scroll back up quite a lot after realising I was not interested in “for customer service teams” but more into “for project managers”. (Nice article by the way!)

text:
A little late to this one but here we go.

In a similar situation and been experimenting with different things:
• tried BOFU/MOFU but next to zero traffic. It works well for credibility when branded traffic lands on our site and shows that we know what we are talking about, but that person needs to have heard about us before (usually involves PR+ad$)
• tried TOFU/MOFU and managed to capture some keywords but haven't seen this translate into purchases and no one moving down the funnel (our product is pretty niche)
• now trying TOFU/MOFU/BOFU with a "content product" - encyclopaedia of knowledge on our very niche thing, all interlinked. The idea is that the TOFU pieces will bring people in and then they will start digging around and discover more information on the topic and we will channel them to higher-level knowledge and down the funnel. Meanwhile we have content set for MOFU/BOFU.
If you want to learn more drop me a DM!

text:
Middle funnel is where I focus & I've seen great results at ClickUp & Friday. Especially if you're focused on `solution aware`  -- even though you may not have direct competitors, you're still solving for a problem & they may be doing it a different way right now. You address that part

I have a paid thing on this, but here's a free podcast interview <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AZ-uXF7L5_g>

text: Hi all! I have a question about where to put content on my website. I am creating a list of the best methods/places for finding a therapist. I was going to create a "Resources" page and put it all in there, and continue to update it. But I also know people use blog posts to draw people to the site. Would it be better to put this into a blog post, and stretch it out into multiple posts? If this is preferable, why? Is there some sort of tag or market on blog posts that makes it easier to find in a search, or is it only better if I increase the volume and amount of posts?

elements.text: Hi all! I have a question about where to put content on my website. I am creating a list of the best methods/places for finding a therapist. I was going to create a "Resources" page and put it all in there, and continue to update it. But I also know people use blog posts to draw people to the site. Would it be better to put this into a blog post, and stretch it out into multiple posts? If this is preferable, why? Is there some sort of tag or market on blog posts that makes it easier to find in a search, or is it only better if I increase the volume and amount of posts?

text: I feel like the outlier by saying I’m not a fan. The text color doesn’t help.

elements.text: I feel like the outlier by saying I’m not a fan. The text color doesn’t help.

text:
Hey <@U02RV7HM4B0>! I'd argue against stretching this out into multiple blog posts for a couple of reasons:
1. User experience. Readers generally don't want to click through multiple blog posts to find the information they need.
2. SEO. Longer content generally does better at ranking for certain keywords, and if you're splitting the same topic up into multiple posts, you run the risk of competing against yourself for the same keyword.

elements.text: Hey
! I'd argue against stretching this out into multiple blog posts for a couple of reasons:
User experience. Readers generally don't want to click through multiple blog posts to find the information they need.

SEO. Longer content generally does better at ranking for certain keywords, and if you're splitting the same topic up into multiple posts, you run the risk of competing against yourself for the same keyword.

text: Thanks! So what about Resources page v. blog post?

elements.text: Thanks! So what about Resources page v. blog post?

text: Is one more useful than the other?

elements.text: Is one more useful than the other?

text: As long as they're both open/accessible, you can likely use either. I usually reserve Resources pages for things like case studies, original reports, infographics, etc. though (whether gated or ungated).

elements.text: As long as they're both open/accessible, you can likely use either. I usually reserve Resources pages for things like case studies, original reports, infographics, etc. though (whether gated or ungated).

text: great, thank you!

elements.text: great, thank you!

text: If these are evergreen resources I’d advise *against* including them in a blog. By nature, blogs are paginated and eventually the position of the content in your site’s hierarchy will decay/degrade and lose internal link equity over time. Which is fine for newsy/trendy content but not so good if these are intended to be fixed resources.

elements.text: If these are evergreen resources I’d advise
against

including them in a blog. By nature, blogs are paginated and eventually the position of the content in your site’s hierarchy will decay/degrade and lose internal link equity over time. Which is fine for newsy/trendy content but not so good if these are intended to be fixed resources.

text:
Sounds to me like great content for a standalone resources page.

If you're interested in blogging, you can then create a post (or series of posts) talking about how to find a therapist, what makes a good therapist, how to assess if a therapist is right for you, and more.

Each of those can link to your resources page and you're golden :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Hey all. What’s the most important success metric to rate your content strategy and investments against?

elements.text: Hey all. What’s the most important success metric to rate your content strategy and investments against?

text:
I think it falls into three key categories:

1. Traffic [Organic + Referral] 
2. Leads [SQL + MQL]
3. Revenue [Assisted + Direct]

elements.text: I think it falls into three key categories:
Traffic [Organic + Referral]
Leads [SQL + MQL]
Revenue [Assisted + Direct]

text: Thanks! I like 2 as it’s closet to how we measure effectiveness in other channels.

text: 100% just a freelancer. I say check on Upwork, start with ~2 folks that have a good amount of experience and high reviews. Give them both the same scope, keep the one that does a better job.

text:
Hi All!

We are looking to get a better understanding of how content marketers and marketing operations roles fit into the content creation pipeline.

Whether you’re a freelancer, an agency, or an in-house marketer, we’d love to have your input in a very quick survey (it’s really quick, I promise).

We work with a lot of content marketers and are running and content strategy of our own, so we’re very interested to see what is working for people and what is not. We’ll share the results here in detail and provide the raw data to all who would like it!

Short survey :arrow_down:
<https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfdbH70KenZsiITde7w0xfmVWjALoJHbclBr51U1hoK0O7DqA/viewform?usp=sf_link>

text:
Hi all!

I need some advice. I work with the marketing team at <http://LOGO.com|LOGO.com> and we’re trying to promote our partnerships (white-label and API) and affiliate program. I’ve already got email covered. What else can I do to reach out to people who might be interested in signing up? This is a new territory for me so I’ll appreciate any tips/advice I can get. :blush: I’ve got more details here: <https://logo.com/blog/logo-affiliate-program>

Happy to discuss and answer any questions. Thanks a lot!
